articles.headline: Justices Take Up Crucial Issue in Wal-Mart Suit
articles.snippet: Some justices expressed qualms about how to administer a lawsuit involving as many as 1.5 million women.
articles.abstract: Some justices expressed qualms about how to administer a lawsuit involving as many as 1.5 million women.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared closely divided on Tuesday during arguments over the theory put forth by the plaintiffs in an enormous sex discrimination class-action case against Wal-Mart.

articles.headline: U.S. Chemist Is Charged With Insider Stock Trades
articles.snippet: The chemist, Cheng Yi Liang, and his son are accused of using confidential agency data about pending drug approvals to make profitable trades.
articles.abstract: The chemist, Cheng Yi Liang, and his son are accused of using confidential agency data about pending drug approvals to make profitable trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 15-year veteran of the federal Food and Drug Administration and his 25-year-old son were arrested on Tuesday and charged with systematically using confidential information about pending drug applications to reap millions in illegal trading profits since 2007.

articles.headline: Where Wal-Mart Failed, Aldi Succeeds
articles.snippet: Aldi, a giant discount retailer, has quietly been setting up its shops in cities around the country, facing none of the resistance that has marked its competitors’ expansion attempts.
articles.abstract: Aldi, a giant discount retailer, has quietly been setting up its shops in cities around the country, facing none of the resistance that has marked its competitors’ expansion attempts.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Wal-Mart revives its plans to get into New York City, a giant German retailer has slipped in relatively unnoticed.

articles.headline: As Regulators Weigh AT&T Bid, a Look at Wireless Markets Abroad
articles.snippet: With only three major network operators, the market in the United States would function similarly to some European markets, like France, according to experts.
articles.abstract: With only three major network operators, the market in the United States would function similarly to some European markets, like France, according to experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Americans, complaining about big cellphone bills that seem to only get bigger is standard practice. But they may actually be getting a pretty good deal — globally speaking.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Kevin J. O'Brien

articles.headline: Foreclosure Aid Fell Short, and Is Fading
articles.snippet: Administration efforts have failed to stanch a rising tide of foreclosures and a decline in home prices.
articles.abstract: Administration efforts have failed to stanch a rising tide of foreclosures and a decline in home prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as President Obama’s premier plan to save millions of Americans from foreclosure foundered, the administration tossed a new life preserver to homeowners.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Washington in Fierce Debate on Arming Libyan Rebels
articles.snippet: Fears that providing arms would pull the United States into a civil war, as well as concerns that some fighters may have links to Al Qaeda, have spawned fierce debate.
articles.abstract: Fears that providing arms would pull the United States into a civil war, as well as concerns that some fighters may have links to Al Qaeda, have spawned fierce debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is engaged in a fierce debate over whether to supply weapons to the rebels in Libya, senior officials said on Tuesday, with some fearful that providing arms would deepen American involvement in a civil war and that some fighters may have links to Al Qaeda.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Elisabeth Bumiller and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: As Economy Sputters, a Timid Fed
articles.snippet: Many Fed officials are worried that they are doing too much to speed economic growth. And once again, the odds are rising that the Fed is doing too little.
articles.abstract: Many Fed officials are worried that they are doing too much to speed economic growth. And once again, the odds are rising that the Fed is doing too little.

articles.headline: Retreat for Rebels; Libyan Foreign Minister Quits
articles.snippet: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced as Foreign Minister Moussa Koussa quit and flew to London, the government there said.
articles.abstract: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced as Foreign Minister Moussa Koussa quit and flew to London, the government there said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BREGA, Libya — Libya’s foreign minister defected to Britain on Wednesday, dealing a blow to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government even as his forces pushed rebels into a panicked retreat and seized valuable towns they ceded just days ago under allied airstrikes.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and David D. Kirkpatrick
